Award.AwardTitle: CUORE and MAJORANA:Next Generation Neutrino-Less Double-Beta Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
A program in neutrino-less double-beta (NLDB) decay is very timely. One principal conclusion of the APS Multidivisional Study stated: "We recommend, as a high priority, a phased program of sensitive searches for neutrinoless nuclear double-beta decay." NLDB decay is the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are their own antiparticles and it is the most sensitive test of lepton-number conservation, an important symmetry in elementary particle physics. If neutrinos are Majorana particles, an accurate measurement of the NLDB-decay half-life might well be possible; it would yield the effective Majorana mass of the electron neutrino which, when combined with the results of neutrino oscillation experiments, would determine all three neutrino-mass eigenvalues.

This award will provide funds to support the USC group to continue their involvement in the Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events (CUORE), an array of 988 tellurium oxide bolometers, at Gran Sasso (LNGS), Italy. CUORE is the successor to CUORICINO, currently the most sensitive NLDB decay experiment in operation. The USC team is responsible for the procurement and production of the CUORE electronics from the detector to the data acquisition system. The PI is the U.S. Task Coordinator for the construction of CUORE-0, the first of the 19 towers of CUORE. It will test the specific construction procedures of CUORE, will operate in the CUORICINO cryostat and will yield physics results beyond those of CUORICINO.

For Broader Impacts, these proposed tasks provide excellent Ph.D. research topics. Another broader impact is, and has been, new detector technology for national and homeland security. A third broader impact is new cryogenic and Ge-detector technology for other basic/applied sciences.

The general goals of the field of Particle Astrophysics is to study the properties of elementary particles that are involved in astrophysical processes. Examples of such processes are the evolution of stars, including their collapse by supernovae at the end of their lives. Another example is the effort to directly detect the nature of the so called Cold Dark Matter (CDM) and Dark Energy. These two phenomena account for about 95% of the mass of the universe, and yet their exact nature is totally unknown. 

     One of the particles of great interest is the neutrino. It is the most prolific particle in the universe. It was hypothesized by Wolfgang Pauli in 1933, to explain why about half of the energy emitted in radioactive beta decay was unobservable. Neutrinos were first directly observed in 1957 by Cowan and Reines. However, it was not until 1998 that it was experimentally demonstrated that neutrinos had any mass at all. That experiment depended on the observation that neutrinos of the three families actually oscillated from one (flavor) to another which would require that they have mass. Oscillation experiments provide mass differences, leaving the knowledge of the absolute value of the mass a mystery.  

    Another mystery of neutrinos is the fact that because they have no electric charge, they could be their own anti-particles. Such a neutrino model was developed by the Italian physicist Ettore Majorana. The determination that neutrinos are or are not their own antiparticles (Majorana particles) is a very important issue in completing our understanding of elementary particles.

     There is a hypothesized rare radioactive decay in which an unstable atom can decay by the emission of two electrons, therby increasing its atomic number (nuclear charge) by two units. Normally, the radioactive decay by the emission of electrons, called beta decay, is accompanied by neutrinos. If two electrons are emitted this is double-beta decay and normally two neutrinos (antineutrinos) are emitted. This rare decay process has been measured in a dozen isotopes.

     It has been shown theoretically that if neutrinos have mass, and if they are indeed their own antiparticles (Majorana particles) double-beta decay can occur without the two neutrinos getting out of the nucleus. This is called zero-neutrino (or neutrinoless) double-beta decay. The direct observation of zero-neutrino double-beta decay would demonstrate that neutrinos are indeed Majorana particles. In addition, the measurement of the rate of this rare decay (or its half life) would determine the absolute value of neutrinos mass.

     This grant supported the University of South Carolina Group's activities in two major double-beta decay experiments, CUORE (the cryogenic underground observatory for rare events) and Majorana. The PI was very active in the initiation of both of these experiments, and was the leader of the International Germanium Experiment (IGEX) the pilot experiment of Majorana. He was also the US leader of the CUORICINO experiment in Assergi, Italy, the pilot experiment of CUORE.
